<p><em>Abstract</em></p>
<p>Biodiversity erosion is a major environmental crisis. Although our agri-food system contributes to the five main direct threats to biodiversity, the assessment of the impact of food products remains limited either to <em>in situ</em> measurements that do not allow for estimate generalization, or to systematic models that are not validated by <em>in situ</em> data. Here we propose the BVIAS (Biodiversity Value Increment from Agricultural Statistics) method, which allows to calculate the impact of food products on biodiversity based on accounting data and public statistics. This method, applied here to renown French agricultural products, allows for a comparison of the main Food Quality Schemes (FQSs): Organic production, Label Rouge (LR) and Geographical Indications (GIs). Thus, among the 25 evaluated FQSs, only Organic products and some cheese GIs stand out from non-certified (so-called conventional) agriculture by effectively different agricultural practices, Consistent with the requirements of the specifications. These different agricultural practices lead to a lower impact on biodiversity per hectare but lower yields, resulting in a similar impact or higher per tonne. Taking into account the main determinants of biodiversity losses related to agriculture, relying on quantified data at the level of farms and validating our model based on consensual orders of magnitude of biodiversity in the literature, We therefore propose here an objective, robust and operational method to allow a generalized estimate of the impact on biodiversity of any agri-food production.</p>
<section id="introduction" class="level1" data-number="1">
<h1 data-number="1"><span class="header-section-number">1</span> Introduction</h1>
<p>Biodiversity erosion is probably the most important environmental crisis with climate change. While the impacts of current climate change trajectories are estimated at several tens of percentage points of GDP <span class="citation" data-cites="rose_cross-working_2022">(<a href="#ref-rose_cross-working_2022" role="doc-biblioref">Rose et al. 2022</a>)</span>, pollinator loss alone amount 1-2% of GDP, and about €4 billion for a country like Germany <span class="citation" data-cites="lippert_revisiting_2021">(<a href="#ref-lippert_revisiting_2021" role="doc-biblioref">Lippert, Feuerbacher, and Narjes 2021</a>)</span>. The IPBES groups and prioritizes five determinants of biodiversity loss <span class="citation" data-cites="ipbes_global_2019">(<a href="#ref-ipbes_global_2019" role="doc-biblioref">IPBES 2019</a>)</span> : land use (30%), direct exploitation (23%), climate change (14%), pollution (14%) and invasive species (11%). Agriculture is mainly involved in three of these five determinants (land use, climate change and pollution), and is, with direct exploitation, one of the two main economic sectors responsible for the global erosion of biodiversity <span class="citation" data-cites="maxwell_biodiversity_2016 tilman_future_2017">(<a href="#ref-maxwell_biodiversity_2016" role="doc-biblioref">Maxwell et al. 2016</a>; <a href="#ref-tilman_future_2017" role="doc-biblioref">Tilman et al. 2017</a>)</span>.</p>
<p>Environmental labeling on agricultural products is one of the policies that could reduce the impact of agriculture on biodiversity. Although consumer information appears to trigger only small short-term changes in food choices <span class="citation" data-cites="de_marchi_dynamics_2023 dubois_effects_2021">(<a href="#ref-de_marchi_dynamics_2023" role="doc-biblioref">De Marchi et al. 2023</a>; <a href="#ref-dubois_effects_2021" role="doc-biblioref">Dubois et al. 2021</a>)</span>, environmental labeling opens the way to several indirect long-term effects. It encourages producers to change their practices, and processors to change product formulations to improve their ratings, and can be used as a support for other policies (e.g., minimum rating requirement for public order, tax based on rating, etc.).</p>
<p>At the European level, the Commission published a proposal for a regulation in March 2023 requiring all companies wishing to claim an environmental better-performing to use the life cycle analysis framework, and for example the EU Product and Organisation Environmental Footprint (PEF and OEF) method, to objectify the claim. France has taken a further step with the 2021 Climate and Resilience Act <span class="citation" data-cites="noauthor_loi_2021">(<a href="#ref-noauthor_loi_2021" role="doc-biblioref"><span>“<span>LOI</span> n° 2021-1104 Du 22 Août 2021 Portant Lutte Contre Le Dérèglement Climatique Et Renforcement de La Résilience Face à Ses Effets (1)”</span> 2021</a>)</span>, which plans to make environmental labeling mandatory on all food products after an experiment scheduled to last for 5 years. Following the proposal of Ecoscore by ADEME, which should inspire the future government tool, several stakeholders reproach it for limiting itself to the analysis of the life cycle of products <span class="citation" data-cites="noauthor_ameliorer_2020">(<a href="#ref-noauthor_ameliorer_2020" role="doc-biblioref"><span>“Améliorer l’évaluation Environnementale Des Viandes”</span> 2020</a>)</span>. Their main argument is that life cycle analysis fails to account for the impact of food products on biodiversity. The Scientific Council for Experimentation notes that life cycle analysis does address three of the five main determinants of biodiversity loss, but recognizes the value of complementing life cycle analysis on some points <span class="citation" data-cites="soler_laffichage_2021">(<a href="#ref-soler_laffichage_2021" role="doc-biblioref">Soler et al. 2021</a>)</span>. In view of this controversy, it is urgent to propose an objective, robust and operational method for calculating the impact of food products on biodiversity. This is the aim of this paper.</p>
<p>We believe that environmental labeling should be based on a biodiversity indicator that meets five key requirements (<a href="#tbl-intro" class="quarto-xref">Table 1</a>):</p>
<ul>
<li><p><em>An explicit and operational definition of biodiversity.</em> The term biodiversity is very polysemous. For this reason, it is important to specify an operational definition adapted to the context <span class="citation" data-cites="santana_save_2014">(<a href="#ref-santana_save_2014" role="doc-biblioref">Santana 2014</a>)</span>. This definition must also keep an intuitive link with the main issues related to biodiversity erosion such as loss of species or ecosystems (and especially those that provide important services such as pollinators).</p></li>
<li><p><em>Addressing the main determinants of biodiversity loss related to agriculture</em>, namely land use, climate change and pollution.</p></li>
<li><p><em>Rely on data of biodiversity or practices that are measured and representative at the plot level</em> to estimate an impact of actual rather than potential practices on biodiversity.</p></li>
<li><p><em>Allow for evaluation of any food product.</em> The environmental labeling must be mandatory and applicable to any product based on currently available data, differentiating both different products (e.g., lentils versus chicken) and different production modes of the same product (e.g., conventional versus organic wheat).</p></li>
<li><p><em>Rely on a validation of the estimated impact based on in situ biodiversity measurements.</em> There are always two ways to assess an impact: <em>in situ</em> measurement and modelling. In the second case, an essential criterion of robustness is the validation of the model, at least on predicted variables for which <em>in situ</em> measurements of biodiversity are available (e.g., biodiversity per unit area).</p></li>
</ul>
<p>Three main types of methods for assessing the impact of food products on biodiversity can be distinguished: <em>in situ</em> observations of biodiversity by species counting in ecosystems, modelling the impact of agricultural practices on biodiversity, and modelling the impact of FQS specifications on biodiversity (<a href="#tbl-intro" class="quarto-xref">Table 1</a>). The adequacy of these three methods with the requirements of environmental labeling is summarized in the following three paragraphs and in <a href="#tbl-intro" class="quarto-xref">Table 1</a>.</p>
<p><em>In situ observations</em> clearly meet the data and validation criteria. However, they are punctual in both space and time, making it difficult to assess all food products. With a considerable effort, the most comprehensive meta-analyses in terms of taxa studied allow an average effect to be estimated by type of product and by differentiating some production modes. <span class="citation" data-cites="tuck_land-use_2014">Tuck et al. (<a href="#ref-tuck_land-use_2014" role="doc-biblioref">2014</a>)</span> distinguishes between organic and conventional agriculture for five agrosystems, and estimates that the specific diversity is on average 30% higher in organic farming. Species number is a relatively explicit definition of biodiversity and has an intuitive link with the main issues related to biodiversity erosion as long as one remains within the same agrosystem. This link is however less than true when comparing different ecosystems or agrosystems because we are then comparing completely different species groups <span class="citation" data-cites="santana_save_2014 sarkar_defining_2002">(<a href="#ref-santana_save_2014" role="doc-biblioref">Santana 2014</a>; <a href="#ref-sarkar_defining_2002" role="doc-biblioref">Sarkar 2002</a>)</span>. Finally, <em>in situ</em> observations have the major disadvantage of not taking into account the amount of anthropized area. The measure of biodiversity is expressed per unit area in these studies, so it attributes the same impact to two identical productions (e.g., wheat), even if one occupies twice as much area as the other. This is a paradox that is difficult to manage in environmental labeling because two tons of wheat have the same impact as one tonne of wheat, provided the amount of inputs per hectare is the same.</p>
<p><em>Modelling based on agricultural practices data</em> is the method used in life cycle analyses. Using such model, <span class="citation" data-cites="crenna_biodiversity_2019">Crenna, Sinkko, and Sala (<a href="#ref-crenna_biodiversity_2019" role="doc-biblioref">2019</a>)</span> shows that the impact on biodiversity in the EU food system is mainly caused by animal products (70-75% of the total impact), and more specifically by pork (19-23%) and beef (21-25%). <span class="citation" data-cites="read_biodiversity_2022">Read, Hondula, and Muth (<a href="#ref-read_biodiversity_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> shows that the risk of species extinction caused by American food consumption could be reduced by 30% by adopting the EAT-Lancet flexitarian diet <span class="citation" data-cites="willett_food_2019">(<a href="#ref-willett_food_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Willett et al. 2019</a>)</span>, and up to 45% by reducing waste. The models used in these studies [chaudhary_quantifying_2015; <span class="citation" data-cites="curran_is_2014">Curran, Hellweg, and Beck (<a href="#ref-curran_is_2014" role="doc-biblioref">2014</a>)</span>; <span class="citation" data-cites="de_baan_land_2013">De Baan et al. (<a href="#ref-de_baan_land_2013" role="doc-biblioref">2013</a>)</span>] however take into account differences in practices within the same production only frustratingly (typically by three levels of «intensity», without taking into account the landscape effects related to agroecological infrastructures, the size of the plots, etc.). This results in very low sensitivity to differences in practices per unit area <span class="citation" data-cites="wermeille_ameliorer_2023">(<a href="#ref-wermeille_ameliorer_2023" role="doc-biblioref">Wermeille, Gaillet, and Asselin 2023</a>)</span>. To remedy this, <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_valuing_2019">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_valuing_2019" role="doc-biblioref">2019</a>)</span> propose a model that takes into account 14 agricultural practices in addition to the type of agrosystem (grassland vs arable land vs forest). Using a simplified version to fit the data limits of the Agribalyse life cycle inventory database, <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> concludes that organic farming reduces the biodiversity impact of the kilogram of wheat (-33%) or the liter of milk (-27%), but increases the value of the kilogram of chicken (+33%). In all cases, the predictions of these models are not or only little validated by comparing them with <em>in situ</em> observations of biodiversity.</p>
<p><em>Modelling from specifications</em>, for the moment confined to grey literature, offers an assessment of the potential impact of restrictions placed in the specifications of FQSs. <span class="citation" data-cites="alliot_etude_2021">Alliot et al. (<a href="#ref-alliot_etude_2021" role="doc-biblioref">2021</a>)</span> conclude that the specifications associated with organic farming (AB, Demeter, and Nature et Progrès FQSs) strongly limit the damage to biodiversity (score between 3/5 and 4/5), that the Protected Designation of Origin (PDO) Comté and the Bleu Blanc Cœur FQS limit them moderately (2/5) and that the other FQSs (e.g., HVE, Zero Pesticides, Label Rouge) do not limit them. This approach has the advantage of being applicable to any FQS, but ignores the practices actually implemented. For example, the Comté PDO’s specifications that limit mineral fertilization to 50 kg N ha<sup>-1</sup> do not allow the quantities actually used to be known, let alone the possible effects on greater cultural diversity or on the ratio between organic and mineral nitrogen. Moreover, this approach suffers from the same limitation as <em>in situ</em> observations on the non-consideration of land consumption and the same limitation as other models on the absence of validation.</p>

<p>Finally, for the three families of methods, appraising the representativeness of their results for a given product type or FQS is currently challenging. <em>In situ</em> measurements, such as life cycle surveys, are generally carried out on a limited number of farms without any explicit indication of their representativeness. This limit may become even more critical as the pressure of environmental labeling may lead some stakeholders to provide life cycle inventories with flattering examples for their sector. The increasing availability of data collected for public statistics and agricultural policies now allows to avoid this risk and to increase the sample sizes tenfold. Some studies have already linked data from the Agricultural Accountancy Data Network (FADN) and the National Institute of Origin and Quality (INAO) to assess the effectiveness of certified farms. <span class="citation" data-cites="jeanneaux_competitivite_2018">Jeanneaux, Blasquiet-Revol, and Gillot (<a href="#ref-jeanneaux_competitivite_2018" role="doc-biblioref">2018</a>)</span> shows that some sectors do not generate better profitability, because the premium product is fully compensated by a lower technical efficiency (e.g., Label Rouge or organic broilers). <span class="citation" data-cites="sengel_performances_2022">Sengel, Midler, and Depeyrot (<a href="#ref-sengel_performances_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> estimates that dairy farms under GI generate 30% higher income per unit of work than conventional farms. This difference, mainly due to Franche-Comté GIs, rises to 40% after restriction of comparison to farms with comparable structure and location, following a «matching» procedure.</p>
<p>Our study proposes an objective, robust and operational method to calculate the impact of food products on biodiversity. This method is applied to the main French agricultural productions, distinguishing the main traceable FQSs for an environmental labeling (organic farming, Label Rouge and GIs). Based on the BVI model <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_valuing_2019">(<a href="#ref-lindner_valuing_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Lindner et al. 2019</a>)</span>, our method overcome three of the main limitations raised when considering environmental labeling <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">(<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">Lindner et al. 2022</a>)</span>. By relying on agricultural statistics (e.g., FADN, Agricultural Census), we access to important sample sizes and operating characteristics that make it possible to objectify the choice of counterfactual to FQS holdings, following a “matching” procedure. We took landscape effects into account by mobilizing the French Land Parcel Information System (LPIS) and semi-natural elements data base (BD Haies). Finally, by validating predicted differences in impacts against the orders of magnitude established from <em>in situ</em> measurements of biodiversity in the literature, it strengthens confidence in the robustness of estimated impacts.</p>
</section>
<section id="materials-methods" class="level1" data-number="2">
<h1 data-number="2"><span class="header-section-number">2</span> Materials &amp; Methods</h1>
<section id="sec-MM_BVI_model" class="level2" data-number="2.1">
<h2 data-number="2.1"><span class="header-section-number">2.1</span> The BVI model</h2>
<p>The model choose to estimate the impact of cultural practices on biodiversity is the BVI model as originally selected by ADEME for environmental labeling <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">(<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">Lindner et al. 2022</a>)</span>. This model considers biodiversity at the plot and adjacent semi-natural elements (SNE) scale, and takes into account land use (grassland versus arable land), landscape effects and intensity of cropping practices. We estimate seven different parameters with a major impact on biodiversity within each land use category: tillage, application of nitrogen fertilizers (quantity and quality), use of plant protection agents, hedge density, mean field size and cultural diversity.</p>
<p>The BVI method introduces a normalized biodiversity value which emphasize on a naturalness objective. To aggregate the impact of agricultural practices into this biodiversity value and include them as input parameters for the BVI model <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">(<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">Lindner et al. 2022</a>)</span>, their intensity values are normalized in the interval [0.1], the minimum intensity corresponding to 0 and the maximum corresponding to 1. To exclude possible outliers, the 95th percentile of positive values is set as a threshold above which values are normalized to 1. The contribution to the biodiversity value of each practice is calculated by applying a response function specific to each parameter , <a href="#eq-1" class="quarto-xref">Equation 1</a>.</p>
<p><span id="eq-1"><span class="math display">
BVC_{i,l,v}= \gamma_{l,v} + \epsilon_{l,v} \cdot \exp(- \frac{ |(x_{i,l,v}^{\delta_{l,v}} - \beta_{l,v}) ^{\alpha_{l,v}}| }{2\sigma_{l,v}^{\alpha_{l,v}}})
\tag{1}</span></span></p>
<p>where <span class="math inline">BVC</span> is the biodiversity value contribution (without dimension, 1 = maximum contribution of practice, 0 = minimum contribution) of a practice <span class="math inline">v</span> for each observation <span class="math inline">i</span> in a land use type <span class="math inline">l</span>, <span class="math inline">x</span> is the normalized practice intensity, and <span class="math inline">[\alpha,\beta,\delta,\epsilon,\gamma,\sigma]</span> are the contribution function constants.</p>
<p>Lindner’s method use a simple average to aggregate these contributions providing the land use specific biodiversity value (<span class="math inline">BV_{LU}</span>), thus corresponding to equal aggregation weights among practices. To take into account that biodiversity levels are on average higher in grasslands than in crops, <span class="math inline">BV_{LU}</span> is then projected into an interval corresponding to the range of possible biodiversity for the land use type (i.e., arable or grassland), in order to obtain a standardized biodiversity value (<span class="math inline">BV_{norm}</span>) which equals the local biodiversity value (<span class="math inline">BV_{loc}</span>; <a href="#eq-2" class="quarto-xref">Equation 2</a>). Unlike <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_valuing_2019">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_valuing_2019" role="doc-biblioref">2019</a>)</span> ’s seminal method, we do not apply any function aiming to maximize the difference between the most anthropogenic land uses and, conversely, minimize the difference between the most natural land uses. For example, in our model, biodiversity is modeled as 1.5 times higher in the most intensive grassland (<span class="math inline">BV_{loc} = 0.44</span>) than in the most intensive crop (<span class="math inline">BV_{loc} = 0.23</span>).</p>
<p><span id="eq-2"><span class="math display">
BV_{loc,i} = BV_{norm,i}
\tag{2}</span></span></p>
<p>Finally, the impact on biodiversity value (BVI) of one hectare is defined as <span class="math inline">BVIAS_{ha} = 1 - BV_{loc}</span>.</p>
<p>Note that here, we calibrated the contribution function constants, the aggregation weights and the possible biodiversity value interval boundaries according to literature values (see <a href="#sec-MM_calibration" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.8</a>).</p>
</section>
<section id="allocation-of-biodiversity-impact-to-farm-products" class="level2" data-number="2.2">
<h2 data-number="2.2"><span class="header-section-number">2.2</span> Allocation of biodiversity impact to farm products</h2>
<p>To assign the previously calculated per hectare impact to different farm products, we follow the common life cycle analysis (LCA) recommendations of restricting the scope when possible and allocating where not <span class="citation" data-cites="noauthor_international_2010">(<a href="#ref-noauthor_international_2010" role="doc-biblioref"><em>International <span>Reference</span> <span>Life</span> <span>Cycle</span> <span>Data</span> <span>System</span> (<span>ILCD</span>) <span>Handbook</span> General Guide for Life Cycle Assessment: Detailed Guidance</em> 2010</a>)</span>. Where applicable, we opt for the economic allocation of impact – that is to say in proportion to the turnover generated by each product – <strong><em>which is both the most common choice and the best approximation of the share of responsibility in generating the impact <span class="citation" data-cites="koch_agribalyse_2020">(<a href="#ref-koch_agribalyse_2020" role="doc-biblioref">Koch and Salou 2020</a>)</span>.</em></strong> <!--# comment from Clélia : meilleure selon quel critère? est-ce nécessaire d'ajouter cette partie ou bien dire que c'est le choix le plus courant est suffisant? --></p>
<p>For crops, narrowing the scope, i.e., relating farm variables to crop scale, allows to directly estimate the impact of one hectare of a crop (see <a href="#sec-MM_crop_practices" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.4</a>). The impact on biodiversity of one kilogram of crop is then simply calculated as: <span class="math inline">BVIAS_{kg} = BVIAS_{ha} / Y</span> where <span class="math inline">Y</span> is the yield of the crop in <span class="math inline">kg/ha</span>.</p>
<p>For animal products, we can narrow the scope to differentiate production workshops (e.g., crops, cattle and pigs), but not co-products from the same workshop (e.g., milk and cull cow meat from diary cattle). The impact on biodiversity of one kilogram of an animal product is therefore calculated in two steps. Firstly, we estimate the workshop impact by summing up the impact of the livestock feed consumed by the workshop: the so-called pseudo-farm encompasses both the farm areas used to produce feed and the areas outside the farm necessary for the production of purchased feed. Secondly, the workshop impact is then economically allocated to the different co-products (e.g., milk and meat), based on the sale value.</p>
</section>
<section id="data-used" class="level2" data-number="2.3">
<h2 data-number="2.3"><span class="header-section-number">2.3</span> Data used</h2>
<section id="source-databases" class="level3" data-number="2.3.1">
<h3 data-number="2.3.1"><span class="header-section-number">2.3.1</span> Source databases</h3>
<p>Reporting on specific impacts of FQSs on biodiversity requires first to identify farms with certified products and to estimate the cultivation practices applied in these farms.</p>
<p>To identify farms with certified products, we use the Quality and Origin Information Signs (SIQO; i.e., FQSs) database from the National Institute of Designations of Origin (INAO) linked to the Agricultural Census (AC).</p>
<p>The estimation of agricultural practices requires data on the areas of different crop production, the quantity and type of inputs used, the average number and feed of different livestock categories and production volumes in quantity and value. The French Farm Accountancy Data Network (FADN), which collects these data annually on a representative sample of more than 7,500 large and medium-sized farms throughout metropolitan France, is used to estimate the practices applied on each farm (<a href="#fig-diagram" class="quarto-xref">Figure 1</a>). This large sample size allows for statistically robust comparisons between productions with and without FQS.</p>
<p>To detail crop management and husbandry practices for different crops and categories of livestock, data from other studies are used as reference averages or as a distribution key <a href="#fig-diagram" class="quarto-xref">Figure 1</a>.</p>
<p>In order to take into account the landscape variables implemented on the farms, we use the French Land Parcel Information System (LPIS; <span class="citation" data-cites="ign_registre_2020">IGN (<a href="#ref-ign_registre_2020" role="doc-biblioref">2020</a>)</span>) and the Hedges layer of the BD TOPO® database <span class="citation" data-cites="ign_bd_2020">(<a href="#ref-ign_bd_2020" role="doc-biblioref">IGN and ASP 2020</a>)</span> to define the mean field size, the hedge density (i.e., hedge linear meter per hectare) and the cultural diversity (Shannon Index). We also use raster data from Sentinel-2 <span class="citation" data-cites="european_space_agency_sentinel-2_2022">(<a href="#ref-european_space_agency_sentinel-2_2022" role="doc-biblioref">European Space Agency 2022</a>)</span> to estimate the soil cover (i.e., number of day per year of covered soil, see <a href="#sec-MM_landscape_variables" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.5</a> and <a href="#sec-SM_ground_cover" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.1.4</a>).</p>

<section id="matching-ac-siqo-and-fadn-databases" class="level3" data-number="2.3.2">
<h3 data-number="2.3.2"><span class="header-section-number">2.3.2</span> Matching AC, SIQO and FADN databases</h3>
<p>The matching of AC and FQS (SIQO from INAO) data is done, prior to this study, using the SIRET number (French System for Identification of Establishments) of the farms <span class="citation" data-cites="corre_methode_2023">(<a href="#ref-corre_methode_2023" role="doc-biblioref">Corre, Pomeon, and Regolo 2023</a>)</span>, allowing to identify farms involved in FQSs and for which certified product. The 2020 FADN and AC data are then matched by comparing the SIRET, Pacage (identifier linked to the Common Agricultural Policy) and SIREN (French System for Identification of Business Register) numbers of agricultural holdings. The matched data set thus includes <strong><em>7292</em></strong> farms, located throughout the metropolitan territory, representing <strong><em>99.14%</em></strong> of farms registered in the 2020 FADN. A description of the matched data is provided in <a href="#tbl-stat_desc" class="quarto-xref">Table 2</a>.</p>

<section id="matching-the-fadn-ac-fqs-database-with-the-lpis" class="level3" data-number="2.3.3">
<h3 data-number="2.3.3"><span class="header-section-number">2.3.3</span> Matching the FADN-AC-FQS database with the LPIS</h3>
<p>To estimate landscape related variables, we first extract from the 2020 French Land Parcel Information System (LPIS) <span class="citation" data-cites="ign_registre_2020">(<a href="#ref-ign_registre_2020" role="doc-biblioref">IGN 2020</a>)</span> all plots of farms included in the 2020 FADN-AC-FQS database. This extraction provides us with a sub-sample of the LPIS that we intersect with the hedge layer of the BD Topo® that we use to calculate landscape parameters.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="sec-MM_crop_practices" class="level2" data-number="2.4">
<h2 data-number="2.4"><span class="header-section-number">2.4</span> Estimation of within-field crop practices from accounting data</h2>
<p>The BVIAS model takes as input variables on the intensity of four within-field practices and four landscape variables (see <a href="#sec-MM_landscape_variables" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.5</a>): tillage, total nitrogen fertilization (mineral and organic), share of mineral nitrogen fertilization and use of plant protection products, and the density of hedge, the mean field size, the ground cover and the cultural diversity.</p>
<section id="tillage" class="level3" data-number="2.4.1">
<h3 data-number="2.4.1"><span class="header-section-number">2.4.1</span> Tillage</h3>
<p>Tillage intensity is estimated by the farm’s off-road diesel consumption, subtracted from the average amount of off-road diesel used for direct seeding, i.e., cultivate crops without tillage <span class="citation" data-cites="pellerin_action_2015">(<a href="#ref-pellerin_action_2015" role="doc-biblioref">Chenu and Butault 2015</a>)</span>, assuming that other diesel consuming interventions are identical between ploughing, direct seeding systems and grassland management. This estimated amount of diesel used for ploughing is then allocated to the different crops according to their area.</p>
</section>
<section id="nitrogen-fertilization" class="level3" data-number="2.4.2">
<h3 data-number="2.4.2"><span class="header-section-number">2.4.2</span> Nitrogen fertilization</h3>
<p>The intensity of nitrogen fertilization is estimated for both mineral and organic fertilizers. For mineral fertilizers, the amount of mineral nitrogen brought to the farm, directly reported in the FADN, is allocated to the different crops using national mineral nitrogen input averages as a distribution key <span class="citation" data-cites="ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019">(<a href="#ref-ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Ministère De L’Agriculture (SSP) 2019</a>)</span> (see “PKGC_N_ferti” sheet of supp_data.xlsx file).</p>
<p>For organic fertilizers, as the FADN variable is not well-informed, we estimate these inputs in two different ways, depending on whether or not the farm has livestock.</p>
<p>For farms without livestock, a standard value, equal to the national averages of organic nitrogen input per crop of farms that do not produce organic manure <span class="citation" data-cites="ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019">(<a href="#ref-ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Ministère De L’Agriculture (SSP) 2019</a>)</span> (see “PKGC_N_ferti” sheet of supp_data.xlsx file), is added to the different crops, distinguishing between organic and conventional farms.</p>
<p>For husbandries, we consider that the total amount of the nitrogen excreted by the farm herd is spread on-farm. The amount of nitrogen excreted by livestock is calculated in accordance with IPCC recommendations <span class="citation" data-cites="ipcc_emissions_2006 ipcc_emissions_2019">(<a href="#ref-ipcc_emissions_2006" role="doc-biblioref">IPCC 2006</a>, <a href="#ref-ipcc_emissions_2019" role="doc-biblioref">2019</a>)</span> and then allocate among the different crops, using the national averages of organic nitrogen input per crop of farms producing their own manure as a distribution key (<span class="citation" data-cites="ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019">Ministère De L’Agriculture (SSP) (<a href="#ref-ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019" role="doc-biblioref">2019</a>)</span>; see “PKGC_N_ferti_org” sheet in supp_data.xlsx file). The calculation of nitrogen excretion by animals is based on the livestock population reported in FADN and the estimation of the feed quantity and nutritional quality of the ration provided to these animals (see <a href="#sec-MM_feed_qty_qlty" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.7.1</a>).</p>
<p>For farms that do not produce enough organic manure, we believe they import and spread as much organic manure as farms that do not have livestock. To identify them, we define a minimum threshold of organic nitrogen input as the smallest value between the national average of organic nitrogen inputs and the lowest limit of the CI95% of the national average of organic nitrogen inputs from farms producing their own organic manure <span class="citation" data-cites="ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019">(<a href="#ref-ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Ministère De L’Agriculture (SSP) 2019</a>)</span>.</p>
<p>At the opposite, for farms that produce too much organic manure, we believe they export their surplus. To identify them, we define a maximum threshold of organic nitrogen input for each crop above which this threshold value is applied as a standard value. This threshold is equal to the highest value between the national average of organic nitrogen inputs and the highest limit of the CI95% of the national average of organic nitrogen inputs from farms producing their own organic manure <span class="citation" data-cites="ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019">(<a href="#ref-ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Ministère De L’Agriculture (SSP) 2019</a>)</span>.</p>
<!--# maybe should we include : 
Furthermore, organic livestock farming and Comté PDO specifications forbid a maximum input of nitrogen. For farms for which we estimated an amount of organic nitrogen higher than this maximum authorized quantity, we apply this threshold as a standard value. XX ref spec -->
<p>In addition, the proportion of mineral nitrogen on total nitrogen input to crops is used as a fully-fledged parameter of the model <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_valuing_2019">(<a href="#ref-lindner_valuing_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Lindner et al. 2019</a>)</span>.</p>
</section>
<section id="sec-MM_pesticides" class="level3" data-number="2.4.3">
<h3 data-number="2.4.3"><span class="header-section-number">2.4.3</span> Application of plant protection products</h3>
<p>The intensity of the application of plant protection products is estimated using the purchased value (€) in plant protection products registered in the FADN. This value is allocated to the different crops using the national average Treatment Frequency Index (TFI) as a distribution key <span class="citation" data-cites="ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019">(<a href="#ref-ministere_de_lagriculture_ssp_pratiques_2019" role="doc-biblioref">Ministère De L’Agriculture (SSP) 2019</a>)</span> (see “IFT_ref” sheet of supp_data.xlsx file). We accounted for the lower toxicity of products used in organic farming by correcting the value in plant protection products of organic farms by the ratio between the average toxicity of products used in organic farming and the average toxicity of products used in conventional agriculture.</p>
<p>To assess the average toxicities of products used either in organic or conventional farming, we estimate the toxicity by dose of four among the top ten best-selling products in each of these production modes <span class="citation" data-cites="eau_france_bnv-d_2020">(<a href="#ref-eau_france_bnv-d_2020" role="doc-biblioref">France and Ventes de produits phytopharmaceutiques par les Distributeurs agréés 2020</a>)</span>. We select these four products for the availability of data to determine their toxicity, by multiplying their “freshwater ecotoxicity” characterization factor <span class="citation" data-cites="andreasi_bassi_updated_2023">(<a href="#ref-andreasi_bassi_updated_2023" role="doc-biblioref">Andreasi Bassi et al. 2023</a>)</span> by their unit dose <span class="citation" data-cites="noauthor_arrete_2017">(in accordance with <a href="#ref-noauthor_arrete_2017" role="doc-biblioref"><span>“Arrêté Du 27 Avril 2017 Définissant La Méthodologie de Calcul Et La Valeur Des Doses Unités de Référence Des Substances Actives Phytopharmaceutiques”</span> 2017</a>)</span>. In line with the ADEME proposal for environmental labeling <span class="citation" data-cites="noauthor_ingredients_2024">(<a href="#ref-noauthor_ingredients_2024" role="doc-biblioref"><span>“Ingrédients Agricoles - Inventaires Mobilisés (Impacts <span>ACV</span>) : <span>Ecobalyse</span>”</span> 2024</a>)</span>, the characterization factor is doubled for organic molecules compared to inorganic molecules (e.g., copper). Then, we calculate the average toxicity of products used in organic or conventional agriculture as the weighted average of the toxicity of the four products by the corresponding number of unit doses (NODU) used in France in 2020 (see “A.5.1_substance_top10” sheet of supp_data.xlsx file).</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="sec-MM_landscape_variables" class="level2" data-number="2.5">
<h2 data-number="2.5"><span class="header-section-number">2.5</span> Estimation of landscape variables</h2>
<p>In order to take into account the landscape dimension in the BVIAS model, we estimate four parameters from the pairing between the French Land Parcel Information System <span class="citation" data-cites="ign_registre_2020">(<a href="#ref-ign_registre_2020" role="doc-biblioref">IGN 2020</a>)</span> (LPIS), the Hedge layer of the BD Topo® <span class="citation" data-cites="ign_bd_2020">(<a href="#ref-ign_bd_2020" role="doc-biblioref">IGN and ASP 2020</a>)</span>, The Sentinel-2 raster data <span class="citation" data-cites="european_space_agency_sentinel-2_2022">(<a href="#ref-european_space_agency_sentinel-2_2022" role="doc-biblioref">European Space Agency 2022</a>)</span> and our FADN-AC-FQS matched database: the density of hedges, the mean field size, the cultural diversity and the ground cover:</p>
<ul>
<li>Hedge density is the ratio of the sum in linear meters of hedge to the utilized agricultural area (UAA) of the holding (see <a href="#sec-SM_hedge" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.1.1</a>).</li>
<li>The mean field size is the ratio of the UAA to the number of plots, calculated based on the French Land Parcel Information System (LPIS; <span class="citation" data-cites="ign_registre_2020">IGN (<a href="#ref-ign_registre_2020" role="doc-biblioref">2020</a>)</span>; see <a href="#sec-SM_MFS" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.1.2</a>).</li>
<li>For cultural diversity, we calculated a Shannon diversity index for the arable land use type of each farm based on the FADN data (see <a href="#sec-SM_shannon" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.1.3</a>).</li>
<li>Ground cover is estimated as the average number of days of uncovered bare soil based on the Sentinel-2 (S2) raster data <span class="citation" data-cites="european_space_agency_sentinel-2_2022">(<a href="#ref-european_space_agency_sentinel-2_2022" role="doc-biblioref">European Space Agency 2022</a>)</span> (see <a href="#sec-SM_ground_cover" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.1.4</a>)</li>
</ul>
</section>
<section id="estimation-of-pratices-applied-in-grasslands" class="level2" data-number="2.6">
<h2 data-number="2.6"><span class="header-section-number">2.6</span> Estimation of pratices applied in grasslands</h2>
<p>In our modelling framework, grasslands are not ploughed nor receive pesticides. They do not have any cultural diversity. The mean filed size effect is also considered negligible for grasslands. These five variables are therefore weighted to zero for the calculation of the BVIAS of grasslands.</p>
</section>
<section id="estimation-of-husbandry-practices-from-accounting-data" class="level2" data-number="2.7">
<h2 data-number="2.7"><span class="header-section-number">2.7</span> Estimation of husbandry practices from accounting data</h2>
<p>Estimating the quantity and nutritional quality of livestock feed is required to estimate the amount of nitrogen excreted by livestock according to Tier 2 IPCC recommendations <span class="citation" data-cites="ipcc_emissions_2006 ipcc_emissions_2019">(<a href="#ref-ipcc_emissions_2006" role="doc-biblioref">IPCC 2006</a>, <a href="#ref-ipcc_emissions_2019" role="doc-biblioref">2019</a>)</span>. This estimate also allows for the quantification of crop practices associated with animal feed, either on-farm (in the case of on-farm produced and consumed feed) or off-farm (i.e., purchased feed). We thus reconstitute a «pseudo-farm» gathering both on- and off-farm surface cultivated to feed the herd.</p>
<section id="sec-MM_feed_qty_qlty" class="level3" data-number="2.7.1">
<h3 data-number="2.7.1"><span class="header-section-number">2.7.1</span> Quantity and nutritional quality of livestock feed</h3>
<p>The quantity of feed purchased is estimated by dividing the value of the FADN purchased concentrated feedstuffs and coarse fodder variables by the 2020 Farm Inputs Purchase Price Index (IPAMPA) for animal feed <span class="citation" data-cites="noauthor_indice_2020">(<a href="#ref-noauthor_indice_2020" role="doc-biblioref"><span>“Indice Annuel Des Prix d’achat Des Moyens de Production Agricole (<span>IPAMPA</span>) - <span>Aliments</span> Des Animaux <span></span> <span>Insee</span>”</span> 2020</a>)</span>. This total kg feed per farm is then allocated to different feed types (e.g., soft wheat grains, soybean meal and corn silage) using the volumes consumed nationally as a distribution key <span class="citation" data-cites="sailley_quantifier_2021">(<a href="#ref-sailley_quantifier_2021" role="doc-biblioref">Sailley et al. 2021</a>)</span> (see “TT_feed_purchased” sheet of supp_data.xlsx file).</p>
<p>The amount of on-farm crops ingested by livestock is estimated by taking the quantity of crop sold and the quantity of crop produced, which are variables reported in the FADN. The amount of grass produced on the farm’s grassland is estimated from national average grassland yields <span class="citation" data-cites="agreste_statistique_2020">(<a href="#ref-agreste_statistique_2020" role="doc-biblioref">Agreste 2020</a>)</span> (see “yield_SAA_Agreste_2020” sheet in supp_data.xlsx file).</p>
<p>The sum of the on- and off-farm feed quantities gives the total amount of feed consumed on the farm. This total feed quantity is then distributed among the different animals using the average French ration in tonnes of dry matter per animal and per year as a distribution key <span class="citation" data-cites="jayet_european_2023">(<a href="#ref-jayet_european_2023" role="doc-biblioref">Jayet et al. 2023</a>)</span>. The proportion of raw protein provided by the feed is estimated for each feed type from their composition and nutritional values in dry matter <span class="citation" data-cites="tran_tables_2002">(<a href="#ref-tran_tables_2002" role="doc-biblioref">Tran 2002</a>)</span> (see “feed_table_all_as_DM” sheet of supp_data.xlsx file).</p>
</section>
<section id="crop-practices-for-animal-feed-production" class="level3" data-number="2.7.2">
<h3 data-number="2.7.2"><span class="header-section-number">2.7.2</span> Crop practices for animal feed production</h3>
<p>The crop practices applied to on-farm feed areas are derived directly from available data for the farm (see <a href="#sec-MM_crop_practices" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.4</a> and <a href="#sec-MM_landscape_variables" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.5</a>). With the exception of soybean, the crop practices applied to the areas cultivated for the production of purchased feed are approximated to the average practices in France calculated per crop in our study, distinguishing organic and conventional agriculture. The share of purchased feed allocated to soybean meal (see <a href="#sec-MM_feed_qty_qlty" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.7.1</a>) is assumed to be imported from Brazil <span class="citation" data-cites="overmars_estimates_2015">(<a href="#ref-overmars_estimates_2015" role="doc-biblioref">Overmars et al. 2015</a>)</span>.</p>
<p>The BVIAS of Brazilian soybeans is taken from <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> and scaled to the values estimated in our study by correcting for the BVI ratio of conventional French wheat calculated in our study on that estimated by <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> for the four practices estimated in <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> (See “soybean” sheet from supp_data.xlsx). For the landscape variables, that are not present in <span class="citation" data-cites="lindner_bringing_2022">Lindner et al. (<a href="#ref-lindner_bringing_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span>, we estimate that the Brazilian soybean production is equal to the third most intensive quartile of the French wheat production practices.</p>
</section>
</section>
<section id="sec-MM_calibration" class="level2" data-number="2.8">
<h2 data-number="2.8"><span class="header-section-number">2.8</span> Model calibration and validation according to litterature</h2>
<p>For each land use type (arable and grassland), we defined: * The boundary of the <span class="math inline">BV_{norm}</span> intervals (see <a href="#sec-MM_BVI_model" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.1</a>) as in <span class="citation" data-cites="gallego-zamorano_changes_2022">Gallego-Zamorano, Huijbregts, and Schipper (<a href="#ref-gallego-zamorano_changes_2022" role="doc-biblioref">2022</a>)</span> (<a href="#tbl-LU_range" class="quarto-xref">Table 4</a>; see <a href="#sec-SM_calibration" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.2</a>). * The response function constants and the aggregation weights (see <a href="#sec-MM_BVI_model" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.1</a>) using the optim function function from the R base package to minimize the distance between our results and the literature values (<a href="#tbl-effect_size" class="quarto-xref">Table 5</a>; see <a href="#sec-SM_calibration" class="quarto-xref">Section 8.1.2</a>).</p>
</section>
<section id="comparison-of-practices-and-their-impact-on-biodiversity-between-certified-and-conventional-products" class="level2" data-number="2.9">
<h2 data-number="2.9"><span class="header-section-number">2.9</span> Comparison of practices and their impact on biodiversity between certified and conventional products</h2>
<section id="choice-of-fqss" class="level3" data-number="2.9.1">
<h3 data-number="2.9.1"><span class="header-section-number">2.9.1</span> Choice of FQSs</h3>
<p>The choice of FQSs studied was made on a representativeness criterion. Thus, FQSs for which at least 30 farms are registered in the FADN are retained. FQSs with geographical overlap are grouped according to the most frequent designation, after verification that the «farm» sections of the specifications are similar. For example, all cheeses with a protected designation of origin (PDO) produced in Franche-Comté are grouped under the name “Comté &amp; Morbier” (PDO Comté, PDO Morbier, PDO Mont d’Or or Vacherin du Haut-Doubs), those produced in Savoie are grouped under the name “Savoie cheeses” (PGI Emmental de Savoie, PGI Raclette de Savoie, PGI Tomme de Savoie, PDO Reblochon or Reblochon de Savoie), those produced in Auvergne under the name “Bleu d’Auvergne &amp; Cantal” (PDO Bleu d’Auvergne, PDO Cantal or Fourme de Cantal).</p>
</section>
<section id="comparison-of-averages-between-certified-and-conventional-production" class="level3" data-number="2.9.2">
<h3 data-number="2.9.2"><span class="header-section-number">2.9.2</span> Comparison of averages between certified and conventional production</h3>
<p>The effect of FQSs on agricultural practices and their impact on biodiversity is estimated by ANOVAs on a linear model, followed by Tukey HSD (p-value <span class="math inline">\leq</span> 0.05) tests using the <em>agriculturae</em> package under R (version 1.3-7; <span class="citation" data-cites="de_mendiburu_agricolae_2020">Mendiburu and Yaseen (<a href="#ref-de_mendiburu_agricolae_2020" role="doc-biblioref">2020</a>)</span>).</p>
<p>Then, in order to compare the impact of farm production <em>ceteris paribus</em>, we use a matching procedure. Hence, we calculate a propensity score for each farm by checking for their standard gross production, their location (NUTS2), whether it is located in a mountain area or not («Mountain Area» category of the natural handicap compensation from the Common Agricultural Policy), the farmer age and educational level. We then select for each certified farm three conventional counterfactual that are located in the same NUTS2 region and have the closest propensity scores. Thus, we determine the difference between each variable of the certified production (biodiversity impact or practices) and the average value of its three counterfactual, and perform a paired t-test with a Bonferroni correction on p-values.</p>
</section>
</section>
</section>
<section id="results" class="level1" data-number="3">
<h1 data-number="3"><span class="header-section-number">3</span> Results</h1>
<section id="certified-farms-in-france" class="level2" data-number="3.1">
<h2 data-number="3.1"><span class="header-section-number">3.1</span> Certified farms in France</h2>
<p>In 2020, <em>26%</em> of the French AC’s population declared an FQS, excluding organic farming (<em>108,702</em> out of <em>416,478</em> recorded farms). We found <em>2,919</em> of these farms among the <em>7,355</em> farms in the 2020 FADN (<em>40%</em> of the French FADN population). Of these <em>2,919</em> farms, <em>42%</em> reported an FQS for wines and other spirits only. Excluding the wine and other spirits sectors, FADN records <em>1,693</em> farms offering <em>287</em> different certified products, summing up <em>3%</em> of the <em>51,971</em> French farms that declared an FQS, excluding wines and spirits and organic farming, identified in the AC. In addition, while <em>37,661</em> organic farms were reported in the AC (<em>9%</em> of the AC population), only <em>2%</em> (<em>686</em> farms) were identified in the French FADN. In this study, a BVIAS score is estimated for the productions of <em>5,440</em> farms in the FADN, <em>7%</em> of which are organic and <em>28%</em> has declared another FQS (excluding wine and other spirits), the remaining farms having declared no FQS and are so-called «conventional farms».</p>
</section>
<section id="model-calibration-enable-validation-according-to-litterature" class="level2" data-number="3.2">
<h2 data-number="3.2"><span class="header-section-number">3.2</span> Model calibration enable validation according to litterature</h2>
<p>Based on the biodiversity contribution functions as defined by Lindner, we then calibrate our model to validate our results against <em>in situ</em> measurement data from the literature (see <a href="#sec-MM_calibration" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.8</a>). Aiming at reducing the distance between our results and the literature values, we reduced the mean distance from <em>2.710</em><span class="math inline">\cdot</span><em>10<sup>-5</sup></em> to <em>9.424</em><span class="math inline">\cdot</span><em>10<sup>-8</sup></em> (<strong>?@tbl-optim_results</strong>). Hence, once optimized, some contribution functions are different from the initial ones (<a href="#fig-BVC_functions" class="quarto-xref">Figure 6</a>). For instance, to obtain the same biodiversity value, more hedge is required in grasslands than in arable land. At the opposite, the same amount of fertilization causes a hugest impact on biodiversity in grasslands than in arable land. Optimization also changes variable effect sizes. For arable land use, optimization more than doubles the effect of hedge density, mean field size and soil cover while it reduces by almost two third the effect of cultural diversity (<strong>?@tbl-effect_size_results</strong>). For grasslands, the hedge density effect is also increased but only by 20% (<strong>?@tbl-effect_size_results</strong>).</p>
</section>
<section id="comparison-of-impacts-on-biodiversity" class="level2" data-number="3.3">
<h2 data-number="3.3"><span class="header-section-number">3.3</span> Comparison of impacts on biodiversity</h2>
<p>For a given area of production (e.g., one hectare), organic farming has on average a lower impact than conventional agriculture (<a href="#fig-results_ha" class="quarto-xref">Figure 2</a>). For cereals, the average impact of conventional crops (<span class="math inline">BVIAS_{ha}</span>) is <em>0.68</em> whereas organic products has an average impact of <em>0.58</em>. The same applies to milk production: while one hectare for conventional milk production has an average impact of <em>0.61</em>, the same hectare used for organic milk production has an impact of <em>0.53</em>. For milk production, only geographical indications (PDO and PGI) of mountain areas have an average impact per hectare lower than conventional. This is particularly the case for Franche-Comté PDOs, whose impact per hectare is <em>9%</em> lower than the average French conventional milk production. However, when comparing these Comté &amp; Morbier farms only to similar conventional farms (conterfactuals), the difference in impact per hectare is almost halved (<em>5%</em>). Conversely, some dairy FQSs such as Beurre de Charentes – Poitou have an impact per hectare similar to that of conventional milk. This is also the case for the production of Label Rouge soft wheat. If we compare products, we note that for one hectare, cereal production has a greater impact on biodiversity than milk production (<a href="#tbl-comp_lindner_BVIAS" class="quarto-xref">Table 3</a>).</p>

<p>For a given weight of product (e.g., one tonne), certified productions have on average a higher impact than conventional ones (<a href="#fig-results_t" class="quarto-xref">Figure 3</a>), even among FQSs that had a lower impact per hectare, such as organic farming or Comté &amp; Morbier PDOs. However, when comparing similar farms (matching technique by propensity score, see <a href="#sec-MM_calibration" class="quarto-xref">Section 2.8</a>), significant differences between FQS and their counterfactuals are no longer observed, except for the impact of a tonne of soft wheat and a tonne of sunflower which is higher in organic farming compared to conventional (<a href="#fig-results_t" class="quarto-xref">Figure 3</a>, <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_crops</strong> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>). When comparing products for a given weight (e.g., one tonne of wheat vs. one tonne of milk), the production of wheat has a lower impact on biodiversity than the production of milk (<a href="#tbl-comp_lindner_BVIAS" class="quarto-xref">Table 3</a>, <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_crops</strong> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>).</p>

<section id="comparison-of-farming-and-husbandry-practices" class="level2" data-number="3.4">
<h2 data-number="3.4"><span class="header-section-number">3.4</span> Comparison of farming and husbandry practices</h2>
<p>For cereal production, only practices from organic farms differ significantly from conventional production (<a href="#fig-practice_crops" class="quarto-xref">Figure 4</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_crops</strong>). First, organic farms do not use nitrogen mineral fertilizers but only organic fertilization and apply <em>in fine</em> almost two thirds less total nitrogen fertilization than conventional farms. Second, organic grain production consumes <em>96%</em> less plant protection products than conventional one. This reduction in inputs (both fertilizers and pesticides) is concomitant with a much lower yields of organic cereals. Conversely, no difference in input use or yield is recorded for soft wheat production under Label Rouge. Similarly, for tillage or landscape variables, almost no difference is noted between conventional and certified productions (<a href="#fig-practice_crops" class="quarto-xref">Figure 4</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_crops</strong>).</p>
<p>For milk production, the feed ration content clearly differentiates between certified and conventional husbandries (<a href="#fig-practice_herd" class="quarto-xref">Figure 5</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>). While, on average, conventional husbandries rely on <em>22%</em> of permanent grassland and <em>13%</em> of temporary meadows to feed their livestock and complement with <em>43%</em> of concentrates, the share of grassland rises up to <em>48%</em> in Comté &amp; Morbier, the share of temporary meadows up to <em>29%</em> in organic farming and the share of concentrates drops down to <em>25%</em> in organic farming (<a href="#fig-practice_herd" class="quarto-xref">Figure 5</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>). In addition, the farms under organic farming, Comté &amp; Morbier, Bleu d’Auvergne &amp; Cantal and Savoie cheeses FQSs are distinguished by a lower livestock density than conventional farms (from <em>0.7</em> to <em>0.9</em> livestock unit of dairy cow / ha of main forage area on average for these FQSs against <em>1.4</em> for conventional farms; <a href="#fig-practice_herd" class="quarto-xref">Figure 5</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>). Among FQSs, organic farming also stands out for greater autonomy in feeding their herd with <em>73%</em> of feed produced on-farm compared to <em>57%</em> for conventional farms. This greater feed autonomy comes from a higher share of temporary meadows and legumes area, and a lower use of purchased soybean and overall concentrates (<a href="#fig-practice_herd" class="quarto-xref">Figure 5</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>). However, some FQSs have lower yields, with lower milk productivity per hectare of pseudofarm. There are two different reasons for this decline in returns. For the organic FQS, the production of milk per cow is lower than that of conventional and other FQSs. For Comté &amp; Morbier, Bleu d’Auvergne &amp; Cantal and Savoie cheeses, the cows are as productive as in conventional farms, but the livestock density (i.e., the number of cows per hectare) is lower (<strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>). Unlike all other FQSs, the AOP Beurre de Charentes – Poitou does not differ in any way from conventional farming, except for feeding their herd with more forage maize on average (<a href="#fig-practice_herd" class="quarto-xref">Figure 5</a> and <strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_herd</strong>).</p>
<p>Besides, the crop practices applied for the production of dairy cow feed does not differ than conventional except for organic and Comté &amp; Morbier FQSs (<strong>?@tbl-results_practices_dairy_feed</strong>). First, organic and Comté &amp; Morbier farms use less mineral fertilization, leading to an overall nitrogen fertilization decrease of <em>23%</em> and <em>10%</em> compared to their counterfactuals, respectively. Secondly, as for field crops, organic feed is produced with fewer plant protection products and a higher use of soil cover practices.</p>
